awd_titl_txt: HBCU-UP RIA: Isolation and identification of novel chemical entities from marine microorganisms
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who need to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Fisk University will conduct research aimed at isolating novel chemical entities from marine micro-organisms. This project represents a new area of research (Marine Natural Chemistry) at Fisk University, a small liberal arts HBCU with over 94% under-represented minority undergraduates in STEM. This project will be used to enhance teaching and learning at Fisk across several disciplines (chemistry, biology, mathematics (statistics) and computer science) and thus, provide experiential learning to a wide undergraduate student population. In addition, Fisk University is transforming its STEM pedagogies to include authentic research in course-associated laboratories, where this work will serve as a model in both organic and analytical chemistry courses, thus having a broader impact on the STEM majors, their professional development, and retention.

The goal of the proposed study is to identify new bioactive chemical entities from a newly isolated yellow-cream Gram-negative, rod-shaped Pseudomonas stutzeri bacteria (strain 35M3) whose identity and uniqueness was confirmed from 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis. The specific aims of this project are to: 1) to use high information density analytic tools to identify novel chemical entities from the newly identified strain of Pseudomonas 35M3 and the impact on this strain's metabolome by co-culture experiments (with Gram-positive bacteria Rhodococcus wratislaviensis, Gram-negative bacteria Escherichia coli, and fungus Saccharomyces cerevisiae separately) or after antibiotic selection; and 2) extend bioactivity analysis beyond the typical assessment of bacterial and mammalian cell cytotoxicity to include the impact of these novel compounds on dopamine neuron development and protection against induced dopamine neurodegeneration using C. elegans as a model system. This study has the potential to identify 16S rRNA gene sequences of newly identified microbial strains. The data generated from this work will inform the design of future experiments that explore other metabolomes and/or dissect cellular pathways central to normal homeostasis of cell development, signaling, cell-cell communication, and other processes. This project will be conducted in collaboration with Vanderbilt University.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
NSF Projects Outcome Report-Award# 1600638

Project Title: HBCU-UP RIA: Isolation and identification of novel chemical entities from marine microorganisms

 

Recipient Organization: Fisk University

Project/Grant Period: May 3, 2016 - May 31, 2022

PI: Glenroy (Dean) Martin

 

This project examined the diversity, chemistry and bioactive potential of microorganisms derived from marine sources.  It represented a new area of research (Marine Natural Products) that was conducted at Fisk University, a small liberal arts HBCU with over 94% under-represented minority undergraduates in STEM.  The study focused on microorganisms isolated from ocean sediment samples and the marine sponge Halichondria panicea from selected Florida coastal areas as well as marine sediment-derived bacteria from the Duck River in Tennessee.

 

This study has impacted research knowledge as it represents the first report on the diversity of the H. panicea sponge-derived- and ocean sediment-derived microorganisms from different depths and locations in Florida.  Twenty-one microbial isolates were selected for phylogenetic analysis based on their unique colors and gram stain morphologies. The phylogenetic analysis was accomplished with the NCBI nucleotide BLAST search and comparison of the partial 16S rRNA gene sequences of the cultured strains with previously identified microorganisms.  The results revealed the identities of the bacterial community as belonging to the Actinobacteria, Bacteroidetes, Proteobacteria (Alpha-and Gamma-classes) and Firmicutes phylogeny. This work reaffirms the phyla Actinobacteria and Proteobacteria as sources of potential bioactive natural products.

 

Other marine sediment samples were collected along Duck River in Lewisburg, Tennessee.  The marine microorganisms were grown on nutrient agar and ISP2 media at room temperature to facilitate optimal growth and the isolation of pure colonies.  The microorganisms were identified using classical methods such as Gram-stained and molecular means.  Microorganisms that exhibited antimicrobial potential (i.e. zones of inhibition) were streaked onto new nutrient agar plates along with their competitor microorganisms.  Large scale co-culture fermentations of these microorganisms along with their competitor microorganisms were conducted and the crude organic extracts from these fermentation were obtained.  

 

The crude extracts were purified on medium pressure liquid chromatography (MPLC) and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) instruments to separate, identify, and quantify the components within the mixtures.  The structures of two compounds were determined from standard nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopic and mass spectrometry (MS) methods.  The mass spectrometry utilized the web-based Global Natural Products Social Molecular Networking (GNPS) platform.  Two natural products were related to Bacillomycin L and Plipastatin from the bacteria Bacillus Sp.  These analogs exhibited activities in antimicrobial and human fatty liver disease assays.

 

This project has impact on both physical and life sciences.  It impacts physical science in the disciplines of chemistry and marine science. It also impacts life science in the disciplines of biology, biochemistry, microbiology and ecology.  It has helped to transform STEM pedagogies to include authentic research in course lectures, as a model in both organic and analytical chemistry courses, thus having a broader impact on the STEM majors, their professional development, and retention.

 

To date, the project has produced one peer-reviewed publication, with other papers in development.  Several undergraduate students were trained in experimental marine natural products chemistry.  They were mentored in the isolation of sediment-derived marine microorganisms, the identification of these microorganisms using classical and molecular methods, the cultivation of these microbes in small to large scale co-culture fermentation processes, and the extraction of these fermentations to produce crude extracts.  They also received mentorship in research training, professional and career development, poster design and presentation at scientific meetings, and in the preparation of scientific papers.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2022
Modified by: Glenroy D Martin
